I suspect a lot of good games are like that
pranking the avoidance community by accidentally making a good game
not that they were meant to be memes, but that they're good for reasons the makers didn't plan
a classic example of this is Slay the Spire, which is heralded as the gold standard of strategy roguelike design

in theory if you do it a countable number of times the successful attempts should have natural density 1/3
im invested in knowing the truth now
cant believe tomo made soulless hard mode
could always use the practice warps

wonder if there's a bijection from the cardinal S := 2^\omega to R such that whenever A is a subset of A such that the intersection of A with every \omega sequence of successors has natural density \alpha, the intersection of the image of A with an interval has measure \alpha times interval length
it's an extension of what you said earlier about 3 tries with 1/3 chance should have 1 success
U means you couldnt even get the worse grade lmao
basically if, on average, every third element element of the natural numbers has some property (eg successful attempts), then the natural density of the set with this property is 1/3
so natural density is basically how-many of the natural numbers have some property

I'm wondering if there's a natural way to turn natural density to uncountable cardinals, and whether we can then relate this concept from the cardinal associated with the reals to the measure on the reals
